properties.name: 1982 World's Fair, Knoxville, TN
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula This was the city of the 1982 World\'s Fair. I went here with my parents and bro when I was 9. The only thing I really remember about it was that their video arcade was chock full of Pac Man. All Pac Man. Like 30 Pac Man machines. It was awesome.

properties.name: A Place Where I Lived Once
properties.description: Posted by Mathyulacottage st. pepperell, MAFor about a year and a half, I lived in the little town of Pepperell, MA with my then-wife and newborn daughter in 2006-08. It\'s a nice town - just the right amount of trees and oldness. The apartment is cozy. The river is frighteningly rapid...the ice cream stand is deliciously tasty...the old paper factory is probably full of nice rats.

properties.name: Baldwinville Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula This is where I went to school from kindergarten to sixth grade. Three smallish floors of classrooms and a basement where they actually had their special education area down by the boiler room. Another odd notable thing was that there was a siren on the roof that would go off at 10am every day and also whenever there was a fire in town. That siren could be heard for miles and sounded quite akin to an air raid warning. Directly across the street was the playground, in the center of which was the creepy secondary school building which was abandoned and boarded up by the time I was in second grade in 1980. Later on in life, that old building was of course investigated by many an adventurous youth...as long as they knew the secret way to get in. Later still, the building was finally renovated into apartments. B.E.S. is still operating as the town\'s elementary school today.

properties.name: Beamen's Pond
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaThe water of this smallish man-made pond is where I spent a lot of my summer days when I was young...around 1983-1986. They had a diving board back then...fun. No more diving board there now...someone probably got hurt. Speaking of getting hurt, this is also the place where I ran mouth first into a metal pole and broke one of my front teeth. That sucked. This is also the place where I got bit by a dog a bit later on. That also sucked.

properties.name: Birch Hill Dam
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaQuite the impressive bit of engineering for something that\'s out in the middle of nowhere. Birch Hill Dam is a quarter mile dam of granite boulders built by the Army Corps of Engineers. Without it, the town of Athol, down river, would get flooded every spring during the snow-melts and rains. Because of it however, the waters get backed up for a three mile stretch of Miller\'s and Otter River, thereby flooding the surrounding forests. (as can be seen on the close up map to the south-east of the dam) Better the woods than the towns, I guess. The beavers love it.

properties.name: Bristol Caverns
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaIn Bristol TN, on Bristol Caverns Highway, you\'ll find Bristol Caverns. I went there with the fam on the same trip we took to the 1982 World\'s Fair. Verrrrrrrrry cool place if you\'re into caves and caverns...even though these ones are set up for tourists. I\'d love to go back someday.

properties.name: Cogshall Park
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula I really like Cogshall Park. It\'s quite scenic and cozy. Also a good change of scenery...you\'d never think it was in Fitchburg.

properties.name: Country Mischief
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula36 baldwinville rd. templeton, MACountry Mischief is a very cool antique store which has a lot more than antiques. It\'s in a huge old house with 19 rooms full of crafts, furniture, antiques and gifts ranging from country, colonial, primitive, and folk items. Many rooms are each dedicated to varied themes and holidays. There\'s also a very good resturant for breakfast and lunch. They have SO much stuff, there\'s a second house just down the street, Country Mischief Plus, in which the entire upstairs, last I checked, was dedicated to Halloween! I\'ve spent most of my visits up there just hanging out and looking at things...I think it\'s probably the biggest collection of vintage Halloween decorations for sale in one place.

properties.name: Denny's
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula Denny\'s. Certainly the most convenient 24 hr. place to eat in the wee hours. I recommend the Hot Fudge Brownie ala mode.

properties.name: Dragon*Con
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula265 Peachtree Street NE Atlanta, gaDragon*Con is America\'s largest, multi-media, popular arts convention focusing on science fiction and fantasy, gaming, comics, literature, art, music, and film. I went in 2002. Easily one of my top 3 weekends ever.

properties.name: Elm Street and old airport
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaOdd that the map here shows "Elm St", which in reality is a completely abandoned old road that is gated and blocked. It was once used several decades ago, and had a few residences...til the railroad tracks were put in over it, making it a dead end on both sides. Now it\'s just an old crumbling road with creepy woods and swampy places on either side. The north end even has a 200 year old cemetery in the woods...which of course had plenty of ghostly rumors associated with it when I was young. At the end of the south part of the road, there\'s a place known to the locals as "old airport". It\'s been said that it was indeed an airport back in the time of World War 2, but you\'d never know, since now it\'s just a bunch of sand dunes...(which are well represented on the close-up map) People generally go to Old Airport for two things; to party at night and to ride their dirt bikes and ATVs in the day. I\'d been there many times in my youth...mostly during woodsy exploration...and it was also a passing-through area to get to "The Cliffs"...an infamous camp site next to the railroad tracks...mentioned in another of My Places. I\'m pretty sure Old Airport and Elm Street will never be developed...since they get flooded every Spring.

properties.name: Evergreen Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula in the land of trivia.... this cemetery has the statue featured on the cover of Twelfth of Never\'s "Blowing Bubbles Through Broken Windows" album. An odd note about said statue is that it is made out of metal.

properties.name: Fargo
properties.description: Posted by Baostar Fargo, North DakotaA homespun murder story.

properties.name: Firefly Festival
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula Firefly is a camp/Burn festival that is similar to Burning Man...just on a much smaller scale of 400 attendees. It\'s in the woods of northern Vermont for four days in the start of summer, and getting to it means getting muddy. But, when it\'s not rainy and not so muddy, Firefly is quite enchanting and inspiring. My band has played there twice. The 2005 festival was awesome...2006 got a bit rained out...but I like it just the same.

properties.name: Fort Independence Park
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaThis is a cool park just south of Boston\'s Logan airport. The most prominent feature of the park is the old pentagon-shaped military fort with it\'s 15 foot high walls. Lots of grassy expanses for frisbee and stuff too... and a playground for the kiddies. ..and a food place for burgers and such. Nice park indeedy.

properties.name: Gardnerville, NV
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaWhen I was young, I had an aunt and uncle that lived in this town and I went out to visit them a few times with my Dad and Mum and bro. Coming from the woodsyness of Massachusetts, Nevada was like an alien landscape. I was introduced to sage-brush, scorpions, and mountain ranges in every direction...as well as casinos and especially slot machines just about everywhere we went, including Reno, Carson City, and Virginia City. I think we may have even gone to Vegas once....but I was pretty young...I just remember having to hang out in the kids gaming rooms in a lot of places while the adults gambled.

properties.name: Hammond Castle
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula{from the web-site...} "John Hays Hammond, Jr. built his medieval-style castle between the years 1926 and 1929 to serve both as his home and as a backdrop for his collection of Roman, medieval, and Renaissance artifacts. In addition, the building housed the Hammond Research Corporation, from which Dr. Hammond produced over 400 patents and the ideas for over 800 inventions. Second only to Thomas Alva Edison in number of patents, John Hammond was one of America\'s premier inventors. His most important work was the development of remote control via radio waves, which earned him the title, "The Father of Remote Control." Visitors to Hammond Castle Museum are welcome to explore the castle on a self-guided tour of eight rooms including the great hall, indoor courtyard, Renaissance dining room, two guest bedrooms, the inventions exhibit room, the Natalie Hays Hammond exhibit room, the tower galleries, as well as several smaller rooms and passage ways. Visitors may also enjoy the beauty of the castle grounds and a view of the Atlantic shore line. In addition to self-guided tours, Hammond Castle Museum offers a number of educational programs and prearranged tour opportunities for school and tour groups." . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . I first went to Hammond Castle for a sixth grade field trip. I went again in 2001 and have been back several times since. They have some pretty decent themed events at the castle, including a couple of Ren. faires and the "Castle of the Damned" in October. Pretty cool place indeedy.

properties.name: Hershey, PA
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaWent to Hershey, PA and Penn Dutch Country in my early teens on a bus tour with the fam. Amish people. Odd bunch they are...but their Shoo Fly Pie is mighty fine!! Hot damn!

properties.name: Laurel Hill Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula I\'ve been visiting Laurel Hill Cemetery since 1993. It\'s my favorite local haunt and it affords quite the view from the top as well as a vast expanse of creepy old New England graves in all of their faded epitaph-filled goodness. Best at night.

properties.name: Lee's Hot Dog Stand
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula31 central st. Baldwinville, MAthis place has been here since before I was born in 1973. People come from many miles around just for the hot dogs...and I concur. Yummy stuff.

properties.name: Lynch Park
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula55 ober st. beverly, maLynch Park is very very nice. It\'s right on the oceanside and has big grassy fields, a playground, a concert stage, and the best part is the rose garden.I was clued in to this place in the mid 90\'s. Later on, Tara Lee, (a girl I loved before she passed away) told me that she loved to go there. I never got to go there with her but I\'ve been there a few times since...sometimes in dedication to her. It\'s a very very pretty place. I guess a lot of weddings happen there as well. Look at the site I\'ve listed and you can go see the prettiness.

properties.name: Mt Auburn Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaMt Auburn Cemetery is in my opinion the most beautiful place in New England.

properties.name: Narragansett Regional High School
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula 464 baldwinville rd. baldwinville, maThis is where I went to school from 7th to 12th grade...class of \'91. What I learned there is the meaning of ignorqance, apathy, and cruelty from the other students and that underpaid teachers really don\'t give a crap. This is where I spent a lot of time being used as a verbal and physical punching bag, and the hallways were often racetracks to escape overzealous over-macho jocks that mindlessly made it a habit to want to hurt me. So....this is also where I learned how to turn off my emotions and become an introvert. : ) I used to think about suing the school for negligence or something.....Yeah, I\'m a little bitter. But, I realize it wasn\'t the school\'s fault that 75% of my classmates were total arseholes. I\'d heard later on that the classes of \'90 and \'91 were two of the most difficult that the faculty had to endure. I concur.

properties.name: Newbury Comics
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula Newbury Comics. For a Wicked Good Time. and Ugly Dolls. and Emperor cds. It\'s my favorite store in fact.

properties.name: Rockport Harbor
properties.description: Posted by MikettRockport is a beautiful little town to spend a summer day at! Lots of little shops and fun things to do. From this little roundabout you can see everything around you.

properties.name: Salem Willows Park
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula  171-185 Fort Ave. Salem, maIf you ever visit Salem Massachusetts and tire of the mostly-cheesy witch-hysteria element which is so prominent around the center of town, you should go to the place that a lot of the tourists miss: the park called The Willows. You won\'t find any witch-themed toys there. Instead, you\'ll find: "Beautiful shaded seaside grounds, scenic ocean views, public pier, bandstand for concerts, picnic areas, beaches, children\'s rides, activities and many eateries."...as well as the old-school classic coin-op video arcade! (my personal favorite Salem destination) They\'ve got Pac Man, they\'ve got Space Invaders, they\'ve got Centipede...and many many more games from the golden age of video games, as well as around 10 pinball machines, air hockey, and a bunch of other games too. There\'s also a seperate building full of play-for-tickets style games like Skee Ball - fun for the whole family! Having a walk around the willow trees and out on the pier for a nice ocean view is pretty much essential as well.

properties.name: Salisbury Beach
properties.description: Posted by Meskipop   019521960\'s Fun Spot

properties.name: Seabrook, NH
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaThis is where the former wife\'s family goes every summer...and I tagged along a few times. We stayed a quarter mile from the beach, and thusly walked to see the sea several times. Nice beach...much nicer than Salisbury to the south and Hampton to the north, since Seabrook is mostly a rental community...not renting = no parking = no day trippers. We got to see the full moon rise from the oceanic horizon a couple times during our 2006 stay. Very pretty. I even saw the sun rise from the same spot. and we also saw starfish, and a myriad of fireworks. cooooool. I\'ll probably never end up back there, but the memories are strong.

properties.name: Seattle, WA
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaI visited Seattle once in 2001. Went to the Bumbershoot Festival...checked out the Space Needle...did the underground tour... Pretty decent place. Reminded me of Boston a bit.

properties.name: Singing Beach
properties.description: Posted by Mikett  Singing Beach, Manchester By the Sea, MA. this is a beautiful little beach only a 10 minute walk from the Commuter Rail stop

properties.name: Six Flags New England
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula1623 main st. agawam, MAyes, it\'s getting too expensive to go there. (5 just to PARK??) and the lines suck... But, it\'s still got some cool rides, ie Superman, Ride of Steel. Best coaster I\'ve been on thus far...even though someone fell out of it and died a couple years ago. Whatta way to go. and I gotta give a shout out to the memory of Riverside Park...which is sort of now co-existing within the Six Flags park. Thanks to Riverside, there is The Cyclone coaster, the ferris wheel, the carousel... Best to go to in October, methinks. Fright Fest.

properties.name: Tara's last home
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaRiggs Point Road in Gloucester, Massachusetts. This is where a person I loved, Tara Harding Lee, lived and died on February 7 of 2002. She was 27 years old. I still miss her very much. I\'ve been back to this place on a couple of occasions....not inside of course, but to the door and out in the back of the house on the dock in Ipswich Bay. Sometimes I wonder if her spirit is still in there. In my darker moods, I\'ve daydreamed about renting that apartment someday. Her passing really messed me up.....she was very important to me, so this is an important place in my life, even though she didn\'t like living there much and it was only for a couple years. meanwhile, have a look at the memorial site that I made for her. http://blessedtobecursed.tripod.com/

properties.name: The Cliffs
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaThe place we call The Cliffs consists of a quarter mile man-made trench in granite that railraod tracks pass through; the cliffs on each side rise up to about 70 feet in some places. From around 1986 to 1991 and a few occasions later, this is where me and a random assortment of other people I knew went camping and basically raised hell...many times. If you beleive in places that can have "weird vibes" and energy and such; I\'d say that my cohorts and I left our mark here..and The Cliffs left their marks on us.

properties.name: The Place of Work
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula Here up on a hill is the place called Lunenburg Crossing. It is in one of the establishments that I\'ve worked the night shift since 2006.

properties.name: The Space
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula The Space, as I call it, is where the music happens.

properties.name: The Space Needle
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaI ascended the needle in 2001

properties.name: Walt Disney World
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaI\'ve been to Walt Disney World on five occasions...my last trip was in 2000. Love it or hate it.... well, I like it. ...despite the Haunted Mansion seeming to break down every other time I went on it. It was the first ride we went on in 2000 and everyone had to walk out of the ride! wtf. It\'s still a great ride anyway, as well as other Magic Kingdom favorites; Thunder Mountain Railroad, Space Mountain, and Pirates of the Caribbean. (gotta mention the Twilight Zone Tower of Terror as well, which is in the MGM theme park.) Wouldn\'t mind going again someday maybe 7 or 8 years from now....

properties.name: Weirs Beach
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula  150 lakeside ave. laconia, NHWeirs Beach. The summer vacation destination for Mathyula and family since well before 1973 and just about every year after that. The Weirs Beach area is basically the centerpoint for the surrounding region of Laconia NH and Lake Winnepesaukee. There\'s about 7 miniature golf courses, lots of waterslides, 9 million gift shops, lots of go-kart tracks, a drive-in theater, two video arcades at Weirs Beach and the second biggest video arcade in the country a couple miles up the road; FunSpot.I was brought up on the area. It\'s fun, it\'s pretty, there\'s a ton of stuff to do...can\'t ask for much more as far as getting away from the doldrums for a weekend or more.

properties.name: Whalom Park
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula   "You\'ll have a whale of a time". Whalom Amusement Park was located in Lunenburg MA, which was only about a half hour from where I lived for most of my life. It\'s been closed down since 2000 and completely torn down in 2006 I beleive, but I went there multiple times pretty much every year when I was a kid. For a youngster, this place was really cool...though outdated by modern standards, it was perfectly adequate for chills and thrills back in the day...and with the lack of safety standards in those times, it was even better! I\'ve got my marker right in the middle of where The Comet roller coaster stood. Shortly after it was torn down, I got a piece of it. Some of the other highlights from Whalom\'s history was the Pirates Den ride, which unfortunately burnt down. The funhouse was one of the coolest I\'d ever been in (they don\'t make em like that anymore) it was DARK in there, with all sorts of trippy spooky blacklight paint and strobelights and all manners of weird stuff in the walkways; spinny and squishy floor tiles, ricketty bridge, ramps, and even a rotating tunnel for little children to fall over in. Other rides included The Whip and Tilt-a-Whirl...and various other old timey bygones. In 2000, when the park was at the end of it\'s rope, I went there with a few friends a couple times since it was only 3 bucks to get in after 6pm...we rode the roller coaster nonstop for about an hour once. A few weeks later, the park\'s gates creaked shut for the very last time. The grounds are still there though...still unused... on quiet summer nights you can sometimes here the faint sound of ghostly children squealing with glee in the dark.... woOOOooOOoo!!!!!!!

properties.name: former site of Man Ray nightclub
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula This is where the club known as Man Ray once stood. It was torn down in 2005...but before that, it was the home of goth/industrial/fetish scene of Boston for many many years. I\'ve got around 10 years of memories within the gates of Man Ray. Since I lived an hour away, I wasn\'t a regular, but was going there about once a month at the pinnacle of my nightclub outings. I mostly watched pretty people dance...and beheld the occasional show by some of my favorite bands at the time. Met some nice people, and some not so nice..... Heard a hundred and one good songs (many times) and a few not so good ones.... and I even danced a couple of times. I do miss the place a bitsy.... But right now it\'s a big empty hole in the ground. A sad sight indeedy. I guess Man Ray is going to reopen in a new location.... but, it won\'t be the same.

properties.name: the Baldwinville bridge over the river
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula16 school st. baldwinville, MAOne of the Baldwinville bridges. What\'s in a bridge? Not a lot if your town has a lot of them, but Baldwinville only has three and this particular one has a river that flows under it. EXCITING! well, it was when we were kids...especially because this particular river would be different colors on different days thanks to the one or two paper mills up river. Back in good ole 1980, environmental protection measures weren\'t quite what they are now. In fact, I heard that the Otter River was one of the most polluted rivers in the state, if not the country. So, that\'s why the bridge that crossed it is on my map. The bridge was along the route for kids going to the elementary school and we walked over it many many times. The river was usually greenish back then. It\'s better now though.

properties.name: the homestead
properties.description: Posted by Mathyula My house is located on Ashburnham St. It\'s a nice house with floors and windows and ceilings. I\'ve lived in it since 2008...will hopefully continue to live in it for a while still.

properties.name: the nearly-lifelong homestead of Mathyula
properties.description: Posted by MathyulaFisher st. baldwinville, maA house on this dead end street is where I was raised and lived for the majority of my life. I know the town and surrounding forests like the back of my hand. Unfortunately, Baldwinville MA, population est. 4000, isn\'t known for much, so I had to come up with my own little haunts...most of which were out in the surrounding woods, and some were in old abandoned buildings.
